title: Relative Clauses
description: Learn to use who, which, that, where, and when to add information about nouns.

rules.title: Who for People
rules.explanation: Use 'who' to give more information about people. It can be the subject or object of the relative clause.

examples.sentence: The man who lives next door is from Japan.
I met a woman who speaks five languages.
examples.translation: 다섯 개 국어를 하는 여자를 만났어요.

examples.sentence: The teacher who taught me English was very patient.
examples.translation: 저에게 영어를 가르쳐 주신 선생님은 매우 인내심이 있었어요.

rules.title: Which for Things
rules.explanation: Use 'which' to give more information about things, places, or ideas.

examples.sentence: The book which I bought yesterday is very interesting.
The festival which takes place in October is very popular.
Korean food, which is known for its spices, is becoming popular worldwide.
examples.translation: 향신료로 유명한 한국 음식이 전 세계적으로 인기를 얻고 있어요.

rules.title: That for People and Things
rules.explanation: 'That' can replace 'who' or 'which' in defining relative clauses (clauses that identify which person or thing we mean).

examples.sentence: The woman that called you is my sister.
This is the tradition that I was telling you about.
The hotel that we stayed at was excellent.

rules.title: Where for Places
rules.explanation: Use 'where' to talk about places. It replaces 'in which' or 'at which'.

examples.sentence: This is the temple where my parents got married.
The country where I grew up has many traditions.
examples.translation: 내가 자란 나라에는 많은 전통이 있어요.

examples.sentence: I visited the town where the festival takes place.

rules.title: When for Times
rules.explanation: Use 'when' to talk about times. It replaces 'in which' or 'on which'.

examples.sentence: I remember the day when we first met.
Spring is the season when many festivals are held.
There was a time when people didn't have smartphones.

rules.title: Omitting Relative Pronouns
rules.explanation: When the relative pronoun is the object (not subject) of the relative clause, you can omit it.

examples.sentence: The book (that) I read was fascinating. (that = object)
The person (who) I met at the party was very friendly. (who = object)
The food (which) she cooked was delicious. (which = object)

exercises.question: The woman _____ is wearing a hanbok is my grandmother.
This is the restaurant _____ we had our first date.
The festival _____ is held every August attracts many tourists.
I remember the moment _____ I first saw that beautiful temple.
The tradition _____ I told you about is very old.
The teacher _____ teaches us history is from England.

exercises.original: I visited a country. It has many ancient traditions.
exercises.answer: I visited a country which/that has many ancient traditions.

exercises.question: The city _____ I was born is famous for its festivals.
Can you tell me about the customs _____ are unique to your culture?
